title: Boosting CTC-Based ASR Using LLM-Based Intermediate Loss Regularization
author: Duygu Altinok (Independent Researcher, Germany)
relevance_why: The combination of Connectionist Temporal Classification (CTC) models with large language models (LLMs) has potential applications in audio-language alignment and enhancing automatic speech recognition (ASR), which are relevant to Haohe Liu's work in audio processing and machine learning.
background: Improving the performance of automatic speech recognition systems that use CTC models while maintaining fast decoding speeds.
contribution: This paper introduces a Language-Aware Intermediate Loss (LAIL) to enhance CTC-based automatic speech recognition models, achieving significant reductions in Word Error Rate (WER) across various datasets.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on improving CTC models individually or with language modeling but often sacrificed decoding speed.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work enhances linguistic modeling while retaining the efficiency of CTC decoding by integrating LLMs during training without altering inference processes.

key_innovation: Integrates linguistic knowledge from large language models into the training of CTC-based ASR systems through an auxiliary loss mechanism.
real_world_impact: The approach demonstrates tangible improvements in speech recognition accuracy, particularly in noise-affected environments, which could enhance user experiences in speech-based applications.
limitations: No specific limitations were mentioned by the author.

new_terms.Language-Aware Intermediate Loss: **Language-Aware Intermediate Loss (LAIL)** is a novel auxiliary loss framework that incorporates linguistic knowledge from large language models into CTC-based automatic speech recognition to improve performance during training.

open_sourcing: Implementation details are available on GitHub.
